issues.title: Confused about client vs server
issues.author: VMatrix1900
issues.body:
> Without a signaling in place between a receiving host and its network, remote peers are able to mark every packet of a flow as important, causing much the same problem as the previous use-case. Eventually, when all packets of every flow are marked as important, there is no differentiation between packets within a flow, rendering the network unable to improve reactive policy decisions. 

I am confused about the difference of receiving host versus remote peers. Normally their protocol stack are controlled by same entity right? Especially now the transport stack is running in the user space(thinking HTTP over QUIC). The text here seems to imply that the receiving host is more trust worthy than the remote peers. What prevents the remote peers commands receiving host to mark every packet as important?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
Nothing in the world can prevent illegitimate packet marking. No matter who controls the remote transport stack or the remote application.  (They are not necessarily coded or operated by the same entity; consider web browser playing a DRM-encumbered movie from Netflix; Netflix didn’t code Firefox.  Similarly, visiting TikTok.com on Chrome is two separate entities, and participating in a video Zoom conference using Chrome is two separate entities writing the client and the server as well).

If the sending host is mis-marking packets, and the receiving host cares about that mis-marking (*), the receiving host can rescind the authorization it had provided to the network. But this is all only within a flow — because we know we can’t control between flows — so the harm of such mis-marking is only to that one flow, anyway. 

* mis-marking might cost real money to the receiving host (network might expect/demand it, else $$), or maybe the receiving host wants to allow the network to have a (useful) reactive policy and expects/wants some packets to be identified as “please discard if necessary”.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: So one possible business model would be charging user fast lane fee. Then server mark packets with high priority and network assign the packets to the fast lane. Then there is a client side agent checking if the packet is marked reasonably. The agent needs to act in the interest of the user instead of the application because it is the user who pays the bill. The best place for such an agent is browser/OS transport library.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: That seems difficult to incrementally deploy.

pulls.title: adding live streaming use-case
pulls.author: sridharangirish91

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: Working on another doc to focus more on signaling usecase.
I don't think the use case and requirements draft should about discuss about metadata attributes defined in another spec.

```suggestion
Live streaming is different from other forms of streaming (e.g., video). Specifically, the delivery of live streams have more constraints on reducing latency to keep the streaming as close to the live feed. In this scenario, video might be prioritized than audio in some cases (e.g., Super Bowl, Olympics, or the World Cup) while audio might be prioritized for other events (e.g., music concert). This also prioritizes latency (to a certain extent) over stream quality. Compared to heuristics, explicit network-to-host information is likely to provide deterministic behaviors to optimally select of the "quality" of the access to minimize the latency. An example of where such schemes can reduce the latency and improve performance of live streaming is discussed in {{MOQ-PRIORITY}}.
```

```suggestion
Metadata for live streaming that prefers video over audio: (e.g., Superbowl game coverage)
```

```suggestion
Metadata for live streaming that prefers audio over video: (e.g., Music concerts)
```
We are mentioning the same video key and delta frames in the below table Tiru. Just referencing Ali's presentation to bolster that claim. Do you think I'll remove the reference?

reviews.author: danwing
reviews.body: Perhaps pull all the tables of Traffic-Type from this I-D, as it is redundant with the metadata document.  Rather, this document should justify why we need a signaling protocol (from client to ISP).

comments.body: To @tireddy2's point, I am of the mind to pull all the details of metadata specifics from this I-D.  This I-D is trying to concentrate on justification for the signaling protocol itself, not what it would (or could) contain.  Specifically, what *breaks* or *would be impossible* without a signaling protocol should be highlighted.  I realize the document is not perfect at highlighting those breakages/impossibilities quite yet.

I agree. My train of thought here: Are we planning to make the justification and then provide an example of how signaling would solve/help solve the problem that we are representing? I wonder if it will be clear enough if we just focus on the signaling without stating anything specific, given we are listing practical applications to bolster our claim for the need of signaling protocol. If we are doing that, then, might as well use the other draft as a reference of how the signaling is both extendable and protocol/career agnostic.

The tables of which signals we would send fail to show how a separate signaling channel is useful -- as those metadata bits could be carried in IPID, UDP Options, IPv6 flow id, IPv6 hop-by-hop extensions, and similar.  That is, without a (separate) signaling protocol.

> fail to show how a separate signaling channel is useful

which I think is fine for the moment as I suspect that there is still an effort needed to motivate why sharing data is useful.

Please note also that we have this text in the draft:

`This document does not intend to define any signaling protocol nor call whether a new signaling protocol, a new extension, one or more signaling protocols are needed.`

pulls.title: explain what harm (pain) occurs if signaling is not available
pulls.author: danwing

comments.body:
I'm more comfortable with the following:

```suggestion
Without a signaling in place between a receiving host and its network, remote peers are able to mark packets that interfere with the
```

Idem as above. 

"separate" is not important here as far as the signal is provided.

The value of having "separate" is to factorize the same signaling independent of the application, transport protocol, etc.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: Some changes from the the airport

comments.body:
```suggestion
    a.  A client based change in priority of a certain type of data is not possible. For example, a hearing challenged user can choose video over audio while the priority is different for other users.
```
to be more inclusive.

```suggestion
    b.  Dynamic changes to priority based on user activity is not possible today. For example, audio packets having the same priority when a user mutes the audio locally, or change in priority during time of emergency where video streaming applications share the same priority as SOS signals.
```

```suggestion
2.  In loss-prone networks or during a reactive policy events, retransmissions cause immense delay. Networks, not able to distinguish between reliable and loss-tolerant data or the critical data within a flow (i-frames, p-frames, and audio packets), can have challenges in efficiently handling/forwarding data.
```

```suggestion
    a. The server (content provider) achieves best scalability by sending a single stream with the same per-packet metadata. The client, on the other hand, signaling the ISP to treat certain packets with a different priority over the others, can help solve the issue. For example, for video streaming, if the metadata just said "audio" (0x00), "video i-frame" (0x01) "video p-frame" (0x02), the client could have the signaling protocol tell an upstream router which one was most important. Some users could prioritize video over audio and vice versa.
```

```suggestion
called 'reactive traffic policy'. An example of such use case is cellular networks
```

```suggestion
radio network outage (e.g., tower power outage).  During such a condition, an alternative network
```

```suggestion
in {{generic-cases}}. 

> Note: some use cases may require seeking for users preference or receiving these preferences. Such matters are
out of scope.
```

pulls.title: avoiding design aspects
pulls.author: danwing

pulls.title: Elaborate signaling advantages for more use cases
pulls.author: sridharangirish91

comments.body:
```suggestion
#### Examples of Same Type of Metadata with Different Preferences
```

```suggestion
A game or VoIP application may want to signal different metadata for the same type of packet in each direction.  For example, for a game, video in the server-to-client direction might be more important than audio, whereas input devices (e.g., keystrokes) might be more important than audio. Each user can have varied preferences for the same type of data originating from the server. Determination of such preferences is outside of the scope of this document.
```

```suggestion
1. Video in a media session: One user can choose to keep the video and screen-sharing equally distributed on the screen while another user can minimize or reduce the size of the video. Based on the size/preference of the video window, video packets can be prioritized accordingly relative to screen-shared content. This preference can be propagated to the server as network-to-host signaling for more efficient transmission but that is out of the scope of this document.
```

```suggestion
2. User Inactivity signal: When the user is inactive during an interactive session such as gaming (activity can be detected automatically or can be a simple user signal of Away-from-Keyboard (AFK)), the client can signal to the ISP to deprioritize the packets to the extent that the client receives some data to populate their playout jitter buffer.
```

```suggestion
1. Bulk data is generally not interactive and can be forwarded of over paths of greater latency. It is treated as non-time sensitive operation. Although some bulk transfers (like saving a file in the middle of editing) that cannot be minimized, where the user will have to wait till it is completed to further use the device, should be given real-time importance. Bulk data such as printing a file while editing can be parallelized and need not have real-time priority. Similarly, backing up of data can be parallelized while restoring of data cannot be parallelized based on the application.
```

```suggestion
1. Client-to-network signaling can enhance the user experience by identifying and signaling the flow's priority appropriately for the ISP to handle the packets accordingly.
```

```suggestion
: Signal flow will vary depending on the nature of the packet. With variety of traffic going through the session, some packets can contain interactive traffic while the others contain bulk transfer. There can be combination of reliable and unreliable traffic within the same session through multiple streams. Host-to-network signaling plays a vital role in effectively forwarding mixed traffic for better user interactivity and network performance. ```

```suggestion
1. Client-to-network signal indicating ISP to honor the signaling data of a particular flow enables the servers, that are not even directly visible to the ISPs, to benefit from signaling. This enables client(user)-driven processing of metadata and client driven authorization of the IP addresses apart from the ISPs' list of recognized IP addresses.
```
